inn1.comm: ooh and straight past Joyce's outside edge - Joyce feeling for it outside off. Not much movement, but enough to beat his tentative forward poke. No ball, though...
wide of the off stump, just shaping away a touch further and Joyce leaves this one alone
swinging into leg stump this time, Joyce clips it neatly but straight to midwicket, before roaring a "no" to Vaughan
nicely played by Joyce, coming forward and angling this fuller delivery down to third man - just opening the face, playing it with soft hands
Vaughan greets his first ball with a delicious clip off his toes. Poor ball, but he just leaned on it, timing it beautifully through midwicket for four
another fine shot, Vaughan cover-driving on the up but smacks it straight to cover
play-and-a-miss, nice outswing from Dave there and Vaughan goes for an expansive drive but is easily beaten

and he's gone! He's shouldered arms and back goes his off stump! A terrific ball, just cutting back in to Joyce who watches his stump flatten. It almost kept a little low, too, and Rankin receives congratulatory slaps from all his team-mates
just wide of the off stump and it's left alone by Bell
just a touch short and wide, allowing Bell to have another sighter
too wide of the off stump, swinging wider and it's left alone once more
another wide...
that's a belter, angling into Bell before cutting away. Bell remains in his crease, prods forward and is beaten
left alone outside off, though the ball cuts back quite markedly this time
Bell comes chirpily down the track - a half skip - before prodding it defensively into the covers
down the leg side and Vaughan whips it calmly behind square
ooh well bowled, squaring up Bell here who again took a step down the pitch and defended to cover
cracking ball, swinging away from Bell who drove, without moving his feet - pushing at it meekly. Not far away at all, and very well bowled indeed
just a little wide of the off stump this time, left alone by Bell
blimey, that's hugely wide - only just makes the cut strip, and the wicketkeeper dives in front of first slip to retrieve
neat stroke, coming forward and flicking it through midwicket
outside edge, squared up by a beauty which left him at the last minute and it flies down to third man
excellent ball on off stump, cutting back into the batsman who is watchful in defence; solidly forward and defending it on the front foot
good pace, left alone outside off
excellent line once more, just short of a length, Vaughan is forward in defence and roars a "no" to Bell
well bowled once more, Vaughan again refuses to flash outside off, just shouldering arms and watching it fly through
a little too wide from Rankin, really, and Vaughan is not tempted
and that's a touch shorter still, rising on Vaughan who punches it to cover
a gift; too wide, and the most juicy of half-volleys which is crunched through extra cover for four. Textbook stuff
good pace from Dave - anger at gifting Bell such an easy four the previous ball. And it's left alone - good carry to the 'keeper
that'll be another wide, drifting down the leg side
wide of the off stump, it's left well alone
and again, down the leg side - Langford-Smith has lost his line here
and he oversteps, this time, the batsman punching him through midwicket for a single. Oh, they're coming back for two and that's excellent running
this time it's wide of the off stump. Not wide-wide, but still wide
errant line on leg stump, Bell sees it, nudging it down to fine leg
very full - in fact, yorker length but wide of the off stump, Vaughan plays-and-misses and his face rather suggests he can't believe he missed it
straight and short, Bell has plenty of time to drop this calmly into the leg side and pick up a single

terrific bowling - the perfect length from Rankin, bouncing a touch on Vaughan who played the most meek of shots, coming forward and hanging his bat out like a piece of limp lettuce. A thick outside edge hands the wicketkeeper a simple chance to his right
immediately he hammers it, but straight to cover
a push past cover - just a gentle push, but they pick up two quite easily
short and wide, Pietersen leaves it well alone
left alone outside off
firmly defended by Bell on off stump
and again Dave loses his line; again it's a wide
how on earth did that not bowl him? I don't know, but I'll do my best to explain. Almost yorker length, swinging into Bell who dug it out, the ball somehow bouncing over leg stump. Mighty close

nearly - very nearly bowled once more as Bell steps across his stump, displaying the middle and leg stumps, and even a touch of the off stump. But Langford-Smith drifts it wide of the leg stump, much to his annoyance
well timed this time from Bell, straight to mid-off
cripes, that's kept low - wide of the off stump, as is the bowler's wont though
no no no, too wide. Mind you, not called a wide. Perhaps the umpire's arms are aching
and that's wide, too, down the leg side
oh dear, another one down the leg side
clipped off his legs to deep midwicket
quick, rising on Bell who fends at it - wishy, washy waft outside off, in fact - past second slip and down to third man for four
on the front foot and it's defended back to the bowler
well, too short from Rankin and Bell has plenty of time to paddle it off the back foot, to mid-on's left, but he can't quite time it
pushed to mid-on but there's no run on offer there
left alone outside off
down the leg side, a neat clip off his legs down to fine leg
slower ball, but Pietersen picks it and it's timed to mid-on
Pietersen charges Langford-Smith - who's only holding cash today - and it's pinged back to the bowler who threatens to throw down the stumps
that's more like it. Terrible slashing shot, but at least there was some intent. It flies down wide of third man who jogs to his right to field
ooh, deliciously straight drive - but too straight, in fact, back to the bowler who fields well
on off stump, Pietersen can't quite time it and it bobbles out meekly to midwicket
outrageously whipped to leg
left alone outside off
magnificent shot. That was almost hit with baseball ugliness - a swat; a fierce smack over midwicket, and certainly not a pull
flamingo-flicked off his toes - a fine shot, really timing it beautifully but it just can't make it over the line for four
full and straight and it's defended
full and straight, Pietersen nonchalantly flicks the ball wide of mid-on, sweetly timed and it races away, seemingly gathering pace all the way to the rope
turned into the leg side, an attempted yorker, and the pair scurry a single
good-length delivery, Bell watches it pass
fullish and on middle stump, Bell pushes it tamely to mid-on
full, wide and swinging wider, Bell reaches and times that well wide of cover point, not with enough oomph to reach the rope, but well timed anyhow
Bell into line and prods the ball back to the bowler
very loose start, short and wide, and Pietersen dismissively swats that through the covers
wide and full this time, and that's just too easy for someone of Pietersen's calibre, he reaches and cracks that squarer
much better, on the off stump and with a bit of a kick, Pietersen back and a bit surprised by the lift but he keeps it under control
a typically wristy whip off middle stump through square leg. Hard to bowl to someone when they are in this kind of mood ...
sublime ... full, driven like a thunderbolt all along the ground under Johnston and straight enough to beat the dive of mid-off, who was fairly straight to start with
again all wrist, this time midwicket in quickly to prevent a single
straight and accurate, Bell plays it on merit
a bit too short, Bell pushes it to the right of Botha and, once past him, it's an easy strolled single as long-on rushes in
Pietersen waits for the slower ball and pushes to wide midwicket
Pietersen turns slightly square and the ball squirts into the covers
full toss, driven firmly to long-on. O'Brien in full chirrup mode behind the stumps ...
Bell angles the bat and gently steers to point, but the fielder has anticipated the shot and is in quickly to prevent the run
wide and Pietersen slashes it to third man, not quite timed or placed
outside off stump at 77mph, Bell takes a stride forward but keeps his bat out of harms way
Bell dead bats the ball into the off side, sets off for a single but Johnston carries on in his follow through and prevents the run
languid drive to a wide ball, well stopped in the covers
wide again, Johnston is happy with that line to Bell, and the batsman is clearly not going to nibble at this stage
Bell into line to block, a much better over from Johnston
driven hard to the left of a scrambling mid-off, who stops the ball encouraged by a shout of "get down, get down, get down, " from Botha
same shot but a tad less excitement from Botha as it's straighter
on leg stump at 70mph, worked wide of midwicket for an ambled single
Bell takes the pace off the ball but the cover cordon is in as one
Bell back and a very correct backward defensive shot
Bell punches the ball off the back foot to long-on
Bell takes a step, pushes to leg and scurries a single
Pietersen turns the bat almost square and pushes the ball off the face to wide third man
Bell fails to find the gap on the leg side
driven firmly back past Johnston and into the non-striker's off stump, and from there it bobbles to mid-off. Four becomes none ...
another straight drive, hit much harder, but Johnston equal to it, he drops a hand down to his right and makes a good stop
Bell drives, but this time slightly more to the off side, and that enables him to take the single to mid-off ... and so keep the strike. Not really what England want
Bell waits and pushes to cover but the fielders are looking for the quick single and are wise to it
punched to long-on

almost yorker length, Pietersen digs it out with power as well, and the ball races to long-on. He makes it look easy, Bell makes it seem like a perpetual struggle. It must be hell to bat with your partner looking in such wonderful touch ...
Bell continues to be frustrated by tight bowling and zealous fielding
Bell shapes for the run but once more the covers are in too quickly
flicked to long leg, and well enough placed to allow the second
too full, but for once Pietersen mistimes a drive and the ball bobbles to extra cover
almost a yorker, and Pietersen overbalances as he tries to flick the ball through midwicket and he can only bobble it to a fielder
firm drive up the ground to long-on
pushed into the leg side, the placement more than the power enables the run
one foot in the air, flicked wide of mid-on who runs round to stop the ball but cannot prevent the run
punched drive to mid-off, who has dropped ten yards deeper as if to give the single and keep Bell on strike
mistimed drive off a ball that bounced more than expected
Bell waits and pushed to cover, for once the fielding is poor as it bounces off the foot, but not far enough to allow the run
enough inswing to make sure that Bell cannot get the ball away
Bell looks to push to the off but gets a thick edge and it trundles to mid-on
full, good line, and Bell can only push the ball back to a grateful Botha
clipped to midwicket
Pietersen plays an almost mockingly correct forward defensive, seems happy not to run, but spots mid-on is dawdling to the ball and so sprints a single. Bell responds quickly ...
driven to mid-on.  Death by fielder here ...
Bell can do no more than dig the ball out
on off stump, punches to mid-on. He has almost single-handedly taken all the momentum out of the innings
pushed into the covers
outside off stump at 78mph, Bell looks to cut but misses
ooh a touch of swing there, and Pietersen tries to drive through cover but gets a thick inside edge
good line, nice and straight and Pietersen stands tall, massively, punching it to mid-on
a firm, elegant on-drive by Bell - reasonably well timed, but without the power needed and it runs to long-on
punched, with fast hands, again down to long-on
again, Bell is back onto his stumps, punching it to long-on and again they job through for a single
whipped to midwicket, but no run on offer there
punched to cover on the front foot
gone! Bell's turgid knock comes to a tame end, attempting to late-cut a straight one from O'Brien...but he could only deflect it straight into the wicketkeeper's gloves
an ugly wide, Collingwood resists
another one, even wider if anything. Collingwood couldn't have reached that with two bats
that's better, O'Brien pitching it up and dragging Collingwood forward. His brother, behind the stumps, is "loving the line" apparently. And why not?
ooh, uppishly driven by Collingwood, to point - beaten by lack of pace, perhaps? Neatly bowled nevertheless
driven into the covers
neatly driven once more into the covers
on off stump - ah, that's a lovely shot from Collingwood, merely stroking it past mid-off and it fairly zoots for four
punched back to the bowler - good line there, on middle-and-off
just outside off, no turn there but Collingwood is firmly behind
defends this quicker ball off the back foot, shuffling across his stumps
ooh - I could've sworn that was a wrong'un. Defended off the back foot
too straight this time and Collingwood is turning this round the corner for an easy single
pushed into the covers
a touch quicker, whipped to midwicket but he can't bisect the field
good length - wide of the off stump, tempting Collingwood to drive but there's a man at short extra cover who prevents a single
a slower ball, Collingwood reads it and pumps one to mid-on. They do have to scamper to make their ground, though
close! Pietersen smacked it on the up, flaying it just past Eoin Morgan at short extra - great effort, diving to his right, but in fact he was some distance from it
ooh and he's squared up a touch here, aiming to drive it straight but splodging it to cover
punched down the ground
on off stump, pushed back to him and the bowler skips to his right to field
the wrong'un, but Collingwood reads it and punches it to point
half a step down the pitch and he drives it to long-on
driven down the ground for another single
another skip down the pitch, but he can't do anything with it other than whip it to leg for a zero
very nearly splattered his stumps there, attempting to crash this through the covers but he got a thick inside edge, sending the ball fine
whipped, aerially, to a deep square leg for another single. Neatly worked, albeit in the air
Pietersen looking to attack now, but again he can't time it, cross-batting it down to mid-on
outside off, it's muffled to cover
fine shot. O'Brien gives Collingwood width, and it's firmly cut in front of point for four
again just short of a length but Collingwood turns it to leg this time, whipping it very neatly
pushed out to extra cover
nicely bowled - just held that back a touch, and Pietersen is almost beaten in the flight before turning it to leg
but he's gone now - a huge wicket, and another poor shot. Half a step down the pitch, it was whipped straight to William Porterfield at mid-on - no power in the stroke, and even less placement
oh, shot! Fabulously driven on the up, crisply and authoritatively - much like Collingwood's first four, in fact - just past mid-off
defended on the front foot by a cautious Flintoff
excellent line, good and straight - and a bit of drift - and Flintoff is firmly behind it
calmly pushed to leg
but that's too short - the pitch is too slow for that - and Collingwood simply paddles this around the corner, to deep square leg
just short of a length, Flintoff comes forward massively to defend on the front foot - with high hands, as is his wont, but it was solidly blocked out
very well played, just waiting for this shorter ball and back-cutting it past a diving gully
on off stump, and a good length forcing Flintoff forward. "Waiting, no" is the call as it bobbles to cover
punched off the back foot behind point
on leg stump, Flintoff is solidly forward, smothering the spin
well bowled - hurrying onto Flintoff who defends on the back foot
an extravagant forward defence
excellent length to Flintoff here - dragging him forward, but he's reaching for it...
and again Flintoff blocks this out, coming forward with a huge stride
loses his line, drifting it down leg and Flintoff nudges it down to fine leg
down the leg side again, but he can't connect with it and it bobbles out rather meekly for an easily jogged single
punches this off the back foot - again too short
and it's defended on the front foot by the big man
too short, Flintoff guides it down to third man - cleverly played
that's a much better length from Rankin - right up there, causing Collingwood slight indecision and hurrying him into defence
straight, and whipped to midwicket
ooh, that's right in Flintoff's blockhole - you can half imagine him lofting it for six - but he calmly pumps it down the ground
rocks back and punches it off the back foot
too straight, too full, but they can only pick up a single with a drive to long-on
defended back to the bowler
Collingwood at last comes down the pitch but can only time it back to the bowler. Again.
smothered on the front foot to end a good over for Ireland
that's more like it, just hitting through the line and lofting it effortlessly over mid-off
oh, shot - and a fine one to bring him past 3000 ODI runs. It was nothing more than a leg-side poke, a prod through midwicket and it was placed quite brilliantly
but this is a good comeback from Langford-Smith, holding its line on off stump and Flintoff rather crouches into a defence
on middle stump, Flintoff again defends with a crouch
heavily hammered back to the bowler and, such was its sweet timing that Dave can't quite get a hand to it and he parries it to the man at mid-on
on his toes, it's whipped to short midwicket
on off stump, Collingwood comes forward and whips it to leg
Flintoff comes forward, hugely - a really big stride, and still he has to reach for this short ball, knocking it into the covers
too short this time, and he rocks back before cutting it hard past point
solid forward defence with an exaggerated, well , defence
oh well bowled - a touch slower, and almost beating Flintoff
and it's blocked out once more
forward, pushed to point and an easy run
flighted at 52mph, almost a leading edge as Flintoff shapes to flick to leg
full toss, hit firmly to long-on
neat off drive past extra cover, Morgan has a long way to spring round the boundary to stop the ball just inside the rope
good line, tighter, and pushed to mid-on
half volley, punched to extra cover
on the button, no run
Collingwood uses his feet but only just gets to it as the ball drifts away from him.
footwork as well from Flintoff, but he just pats the ball back
down the leg side, Flintoff looks to sweep, misses, and it also scoots past the keeper. He gave that extra pace to fool the batsman. but Flintoff, instead of coming down the track, stayed put
plopped into the leg side
two steps and an ugly heave from Flintoff, which he misses, and the ball thumps into his ample thighs
he's struggling with Flintoff, almost paying for trying to out-think the batsman
well recovered, on the right spot and treated with the utmost respect by Flintoff
full, Collingwood drives back at the bowler with no pace
full toss, pushed up to long-on
driven to mid-on who is in level with the stumps, he dives and there's no run
punches to extra cover who dives and saves another one

driven square through the covers, Mooney's return from the deep is good, and had that hit then Flintoff was out ... in the time it took for the keeper to gather and whip off the bails, he had made a yard and was safe
right up in the blockhole, dug out but no more than that
right up in the groove again, super bowling
Flintoff frees his arms and lofts the ball over midwicket, it bounces a foot inside the rope
gently pushed into the leg side, midwicket's dive is not really that impressive, the ball goes under him and they run the single
this time midwicket does what he's there for
and again midwicket scrambles to his right to save the run
Collingwood steps right back, waits, and then caresses the ball to long-on
pushed, a bit uppishly, into the leg side, safe, however
firm drive but a good diving stop by Morgan at extra cover
swept - premeditated - from on off stump, up and over backward square leg, well timed and safe as he knew there was nobody out there
Botha drifts to leg and Collingwood helps the ball on its way to long leg
tip and run into the off side
upright and correct forward defensive
a big stride and a leg-side swipe ... and a leg-side miss
a cry of anguish from Botha as Flintoff edgily works that round the corner
Collingwood does the same, but as he middles it it goes quicker to the fielder
much the same once again, but Collingwood places this wide of the man on the one
hard-handed push to extra cover
Flintoff stands tall, waits and pushes the ball into space
steered to short third man
fullish and driven up to long-on, the keeper sensed the fielder was slow and called "one run" but the batsmen were already on their way back for the second
cut to point where it is well stopped
Flintoff still trying to find the gap square on the off, but he's only finding fielders
full on leg stump, Flintoff had to settle for working it to deep midwicket
clip-drive into space on the leg side, again the man in the deep in quickly to prevent the second
steps back, thumps the ball, and Morgan at cover cannot prevent the run but he made a good stop to save the second
placed into a big gap on the off side
good line and length, pushed back to the bowler
turned wide of midwicket for the single
Flintoff looks for the deft touch, but once more it's straight to short third man
firm drive, yet another good stop to his right by Morgan
turned off leg stump but right into the hands of midwicket
swept off middle stump, down on one knee very early and then hit high and sweetly to backward square leg
mid-on in quickly to field
a sniff of inswing, full and pushed to extra cover
dribbled to long-on
a firm drive, the ball shoots across the outfield to long-off. No effort in the shot, but it went like a tracer bullet
hit high and hard into the deep, long-off has to move some way to his left to field
leg-stump yorker, just about dug out but the ball races past the stumps at the striker's end ... how did he get so much power on that?
a swish to leg, but he didn't get hold of it and the ball just about reaches deep midwicket
full toss - he was going for the off-stump yorker - driven up the ground to long-off
Flintoff leans back and cracks that to long-on. More effort but as it was not timed, it didn't have the power
... but that one did ... Collingwood leans back and hammers that past the bowler - it was to his right but had it been straight, he would have been better off ducking
clubbed down to long-on
neatly dabbed down to third man, cross-battedly
oh dear. Flintoff attempts to late-cut the spinner, gets a thick inside edge as the ball canons into his off stump
on middle-and-leg, nudged back to the bowler who fields to his right
poor, lazy stroke from Nixon, attempting to drive it through the covers but he didn't play nearly straight enough, the bat twisting in his hands and it flies through to the wicketkeeper
better - hit straighter this time, down to long-off and he scampers through for a single
and he starts on leg stump, allowing Nixon to easily turn it to leg for a well-judged single
well, that's very well bowled - holding back his pace, swinging it into the batsman who can't really time it and it runs tamely to mid-off
on leg stump, Nixon pulls it around the corner - just for a single
again Collingwood can't really get on top of it, just sponging it down to long-on. But he runs well to pick up two, and his fifty
forward comes Nixon, whipping this with strong wrists in front of square
yorker length, Collingwood creams it pleasingly well, but straight to extra cover for a single
clubbed over the top. Didn't quite get hold of it, and it sailed tantalisingly over mid-off's head - but cleared it with ease
quicker and straighter allowing him to work it to leg. Good fielding at midwicket prevents two
down the pitch, giving himself room - the bowler follows him, but Nixon simply swings through the line, powering it over mid-on's head
a full toss outside the left hander's leg stump which rather takes him by surprise, and he pulls it powerfully but straight to the sweeper
ah, that's quality from Collingwood, crisply slogging this well in front of square over midwicket. That was sweetly timed
well bowled! A slower ball outside off which completely foxes Collingwood who just found thin air and not a lot else
a vast appeal from the wicketkeeper, O'Brien, to one which raps Nixon on the pads...way, way outside the leg stump. His appeal falls on deaf ears
now that's big, right in Collingwood's blockhole and he simply swings it over midwicket for a very massive six
worked around the corner for a single
whipped with a heavy bottom hand, but he can't beat long-on
ooh and he really hammers this, square, but without timing it. A sort of flat-batted cut on the front foot

well he's got hold of this, slogging it to William Porterfield at long-on who dives and gets his hands to it, does he? He's not sure - it's a terrific attempt, diving full stretch, but he admits he isn't too sure. Replays suggest the ball rocketed into his diving left hand, but slipped through
well, it's well timed - but the placement is poor, turning it straight to deep square leg
full toss and he sweeps it behind square, along the ground, to deep square leg. That really is well played indeed
ooh and it skies this down to third man - attempting to hit it over long-on - but it falls short of the man down there
and now Nixon's skied one - well, not so much a skier as a mistimed splodge over mid-on. That too could've gone anywhere

oh dear! Collingwood slog sweeps this wide of the man at long-on...who remains completely, rather embarrassingly static. He holds up his hands as if to say "what? Where?" as the balls just creeps over for six
ooh and he's squared up again, the ball ballooning back to the bowler who roars an appeal, but replays show he hit it into the ground. Ground-boot
my word - shot of the day, I reckon. He has fairly shot that, flat, over long-on

but it doesn't come off this time, as he attempts the same shot but skies it to mid-on; Eoin Morgan sprints in and almost misjudges it, requiring a dive, but he gets his hands to it to take a fine catch
worked through midwicket and they'll only get one here. Oh - excellent running from Bopara and they sprint through for two as deep midwicket is rather slow to respond
slogged over midwicket this time - hesitation from the pair there, but he races through for a single
a slower ball which he works behind square, calmly
high, high, high and handsome. That came down with snow on it - a terrific, free-flowing loft over long-on
he can pump it to long-on to give Collingwood the strike, that's what
full, very full, and Collingwood digs it out to long-on once more
pulls it to mid-on and they scamper through for a single. In comes the throw - Collingwood's going to be short here, and Johnston collects with his left hand before shattering the stumps
full toss which Bopara swings through midwicket, but just for two

ah, well bowled - a slower ball and he just can't get hold of it, clubbing it meekly to long-off and they come back for two. The throw was fierce and powerful, but too wide - leaving the wicketkeeper, O'Brien too much to do
shot! The most elegant of lofted drives to end England's innings, just lifting it over the bowler's head for four - and it very nearly fell for six

inn2.comm: and he starts with a rather wide delivery which is left alone
better line on middle-and-leg and Porterfield (not Bray as I said earlier, apologies) works it to leg
ooh and a good line here just outside off stump which Porterfield shapes to play, but leaves alone. Wisely so

curving into Porterfield who very neatly works it through midwicket and Vaughan gives chase. Oh blimey, will his knee hold up? Yes, yes it does - and he survives a slide to save four which, frankly, is a miracle
that is dreadful from Anderson, miles down the leg side - and Nixon can't collect, despite a valiant dive to his right
but Anderson corrects his line this time, and Bray's loose drive hands Bopara a catch - a fine catch indeed as Bray slashed Anderson, hard, to him in the gully
good leave from Morgan, just on his off stump and cutting away a touch. He shoulders arms
and it's short of a length, and quick (88mph, 142ish kph), left alone by the batsman
beaten. Nicely bowled, just shaping across Porterfield who wafts his bat at it ungainly
rapped on the pads, but he's hit outside the line
ooh and another good piece of bowling; Porterfield came forward, and just pulled his bat inside the line at the last moment
just short of a length, short enough for the batsman to rock back and defend off the back foot
a lovely shot, check-driving Mahmood but straight to mid-off
well bowled, but a very poor stroke - swinging and missing outside his off stump. Perhaps beaten by the swing but, either way, that was a nervous stroke
excellent line from Anderson, this one angling across the batsman who leaves alone (rightly so, too)
too wide of the off stump from Anderson and it's prodded off the back foot, past point and down to third man for the most splendid of singles
perhaps a touch harsh, being wided for that one down the leg side. Well - perhaps not
too straight again; clipped to deep backward square leg for another single
on leg stump and worked to the Irish Englishman, Joyce, at short midwicket who fields
yet again it's on leg stump - the wrong line and length - and it's worked again into midwicket
but this too is well wide of the off stump...
just a touch straighter, but not by much. He and Anderson really need to attack middle-and-off
he does adjust his line this time, but it's too straight and nudged to leg for a single

oh and he's hit him on the body, the ball bobbling to leg - but here comes Mahmood, racing down the pitch in about two-and-a-half strides, picking it up and reverse-flicking the ball onto the stumps. Superb piece of fielding and replays show he's an inch short
and it's left alone outside off
too wide of the off stump, left alone
on off stump, and splodged to mid-on
crashed to cover, but straight to cover
down on one knee, a lovely looking drive but again it's hit straight to cover
full, driven to mid-off
ooh a fine delivery here, fine delivery passing by a rather indecisive forward  defence
and it's clunked to cover to end the over
just a touch too short and he angles it, very nicely, down to third man
really fine shot and again Vaughan's knee and hamstring are tested to the full as he sprints (well...) to save four at deep extra cover. Lovely, punching shot off the back foot
quick, and it hurries the batsman who works it to leg
quick and defended on the front foot
just short of a length and it's whipped through midwicket. Monty gives chase and saves four - pointing to the ball, as if Anderson - in a relay move - wasn't sure what to do
nudged off his hip
his first slower ball but it comes out all wrong, ballooning to the batsman as a full toss
ah, well bowled Anderson, just shaping this across the batsman who plays and misses
oh hello, what's he up to here? Charging Anderson ala Ian Bell, but the ball balloons off his pads
shot. Hit straight down the ground for four, sweetly timed - closing the face of the bat, slightly, but timing it very well
Anderson sends this one down shorter but it's too short, and it's pulled around the corner
on off stump, the batsman crouches into a drive and - down on one knee - pings it into the covers. They run well for a single
that's a cracking ball, quick and flying straight past the outside edge
ooh and very nearly a wicket with his first ball, cutting it and the ball was inches away from shattering into his stumps
crisply cut to cover
and he stands tall, driving it elegantly to mid-off
neatly bowled, but the batsman plays this comfortably, just rocking back and timing it through midwicket
solidly forward to this one just outside off, pushing it out into the covers
a touch wider, a touch shorter, inviting the batsman to cut, which he does, but straight to the fielder
defended out to point
and it's on off stump, forward comes the batsman, pushing it calmly out into the off  side
well bowled, but well left; pushing this across the batsman who almost shaped to play at it, before raising his arms
no no, wrong line. Too straight, and Anderson gifts two runs to a nudging nudge to leg
flayed on the up, zooting it down to third man
much better from Anderson - quite why he is incapable of bowling six balls in the same area is beyond me. On off stump and, believe it or not, it's defended
left alone outside off
too wide to trouble the batsman who leaves it alone
just a touch straighter, and he shuffles across to defend
defended on the back foot
good line from Flintoff, and it's defended on the back foot

bosh - take that. Smashed through the covers on the up but Ian Bell - cap carefully position, sleeves rolled up, sponsored-sunnies in place - sprints and dives, saving four. Really fine piece of fielding
and it's left alone outside off
too straight, whipped to midwicket and Monty fields
straight at 85mph, met with a solid block
a tad shorter, O'Brien works it off his hips to midwicket

dropped ... short, pulled off the top of the bat to midwicket, Joyce jumped and got both hands to it high above his head and dropped a simple chance. It was high, for sure, but it had no pace on it. Joyce is having a nightmare. The only excuse is that perhaps he thought it would come to him harder than it did
slower ball - 66mph - well read and blocked into the off
defensive push, good bowling, solid batting
another slower ball, Porterfield drives and the ball squirts off the bottom and trickles to Nixon
lovely shot, a little width and hammered through the off side. Timed beautifully and a classic stroke
worked off his hips into space on the leg side
Flintoff once more drifts to leg, another confident flick to deep midwicket
slanted across the left-hander, that's the line he is looking for and Porterfield shoulders arms
firm straight drive to the right of Flintoff, Pietersen at mid-on dives to his left and makes a tumbling one-handed stop as the ball seemed almost past him
mistimed drive, the ball squirms off the inside edge into the leg side. A very ungentlemanly expletive is picked up by the stump mic ...
a peach, 80mph and Porterfield played inside the line and was beaten all ends up
faster - 86mph - and this time no movement - the previous ball swung a little - and Porterfield right into line to block
firm push to mid-off - "wait on it, wait on it," is the call - but nothing doing
fuller, again driven, but with extra cover moving in quickly and mid-off behind him, there's not going to be a run there
slower ball, Porterfield deceived, the ball arcs into the covers and Bopara dives forward but cannot quite stretch far enough and takes the ball on the half volley
prodded into the leg side
a rather stiff loosener, steered to point
good line, and up in the blockhole
pushed to cover - "get it, get it, get it," shouts Nixon. Like he was going to usher it past ...
slog-sweep up and over midwicket, premeditated, uppish, but safe. Not middled, so only two
narked round the corner for a leg bye
well-timed push past short extra cover, not enough on it to beat the chasing pack, however
leg-stump line, the finest of tickles beats the man at long leg who was too square to cut it off
two steps, a big swing, and inside edge onto pad, and the ball squirts close to the off stump and Nixon dives to his left to gather
run down to third man, they spot Panesar and take on his arm ... and win
once more to third man, this time Panesar on it quickly and no more than the one this time
quicker - 87mph - and Porterfield into line to defend up to short extra cover
Mahmood bang on the button again
Collingwood gives a hint of width and O'Brien on it so quickly to cut square. Super shot, got what it deserved
slower ball - 61mph - right through O'Brien and Nixon whips the bails off
straight and right up to the bat, O'Brien blocks cautiously
pushed to backward point, Bopara picks up and throws down the non-striker's stumps ... O'Brien saw the danger and threw himself full length and made his ground by a yard
pushed gently to cover
tip-and-run, and a good one into the leg side
angled in from round the wicket, the ball thuds into the pads and into the leg side
full, a little wide, steered to backward point
the angle is making it hard for the batsman, angled in from wide of the crease, not allowing him any room to free his arms
worked from off stump to mid-on who, for some reason, is standing in no-man's land, not saving the one or protecting the boundary
steered to third man
attempted straight drive, but not timed and it barely gets off the cut strip
fullish, little pace, and pushed to cover
solid and nagging from Collingwood, on middle and off, no room for anything flash
wide and slashed one bounce to third man
mistimed drive ... the mistiming has a lot to do with Collingwood's pace, which is forcing the batsmen to try and thump him whereas with the quicker men they can use the speed of the ball
swept from middle stump, but right to short fine leg. Two yards either side and it was four ...
tight line again, nothing more than a defensive push to mid-on possible
driven to point, well stopped
outside off stump and for once there is no footwork from Porterfield and he misses a half-hearted jab
full, checked drive to short extra cover
angled in at the body, again nothing more than a push to cover
a tame end ... Porterfield looked to whip the ball through midwicket, but only got a thick leading edge and the ball ever so gently looped up to short extra cover
wide and left, completing a wicket maiden
worked to deep square leg
pushed to deepish mid-on, easy one despite a good, one-handed pick up and throw
rather limp prod outside off stump, a poor shot, especially given that Vaughan has brought in a slip
shorter and faster, it bounced more and went over the bat as Botha leaned back and swiped
back on a conventional line and length, and treated with a conventional block
down the leg side, no real bounce either, and Nixon takes the ball well as it scoots through to him
wide, so much so that Botha had to reach for it, and his slash to third man was quite safe
whipped to leg
the wrong line here, drifting down leg and it's flicked off his pads with immense amounts of flickery
comes forward to defend this on the front foot, which he does, but it's a no ball
ah, fine shot, cutting this hard off the back foot behind gully. A touch of elegance in that stroke
and more elegance, stroking this to mid-off but without sufficient timing
good line from Flintoff, attacking the off stump and forcing the batsman forward
pushed out into the covers
quick and short, too wide, and it's cut past point
nicely bowled, Montster, on off stump and it's padded away
very nearly chops hits on - a cross-batted sponge sees the ball narrowly evade his off stump
smashed down the ground but long-off retrieves
too straight and it's worked to leg with ease
classily turned around the corner
and a good start, flighting this on middle stump
and he skips down the pitch, turning his wrists
full, and he tries to hammer it but can only dobble it back to the bowler
touch too short and wide, but the batsman can't quite time it
on middle stump, it's punched to mid-on
and a good end to a tidy over, on middle stump forcing the defensive
half an appeal as the batsman is rapped on the hip
too short from Monty allowing the batsman to turn him to leg
oh, that's missed everyone; the attempted sweep from the batsman, to a ball well wide of the off stump, and Nixon can't get down in time
elegantly timed to "Keeevvvvin" Pietersen, as Nixon called him, at mid-on
big appeal from Nixon and Monty to one which he drove at, and it spat a touch out of the rough. I must say, I did hear a noise...
defended on the front foot
down the leg side and that'll be a wide
nicely chipped down the ground there. Good use of the feet too
on leg stump and it's worked further to leg, off the pads
much better from Vaughan - a nice bit of drift there, landing it on off stump and there's a bit of turn too. Defended
skips down the pitch and whips it to leg
ooh and he's rapped on the pads trying to sweep. Much slower that time
much too short but the batsman's cut finds deep extra cover
late cut to third man
pushed back to the bowler
and this one bobbles off his pads as he attempts to hit him over the top
defended on the front foot
on leg stump, worked to midwicket
ooh - well played in the end, but it was a touch quicker and hurried the batsman's flicking-to-leg flick shot
skips down the pitch before defending
again half a step down the pitch, driving it to mid-on
flatter from Vaughan, timed down to mid-on
and he hits it high, up in the air, but Mahmood can't quite get there in time
rapped on the pads but that was well outside leg
swept - in the air! But it falls short of third man
and he tries to reverse-sweep but misses
nicely slogged out into cow corner
pushed to cover
really well played, just coming solidly forward and turning it to leg
smacked to long-on
the wrong line from Monty - it's just too straight and is easily worked to midwicket
takes half a step down the pitch, hitting it to mid-on
ah, well bowled - he held that one back a touch, almost foxing the batsman who was quick to defend
skipped down the pitch and nudged it past mid-on to bring up his fifty
sliced aerially - intentionally but safely - over the covers
lovely shot there, just chipping it over Vaughan's head. No great power in the stroke, but cheekily deft
oooh, quicker: Vaughan raises fingers to temples in anguish as it very nearly snuck through. Fairly certain snuck isn't a word, equally sure I'm not meant to use it, but it just felt right
late cut down to third man, very cannily played
and a play-and-a-miss! Well bowled Monty, rushing that past the left hander
again too quick and it's whipped to leg. Can't time it
and he can't time it again
slog-swept, but it's top-edged and skied to Flintoff at mid-on who has to jog in about five metres, sliding down on his knees to take it grass-level
square-driven for a quick single
on leg stump, turned around the corner
a skip down the pitch and it's defended
ooh, careful - again he charges down the pitch like a man possessed, and only just gets his pad in the way. Close to being stumped
calmly turned around the corner
punched back to Vaughan
neatly turned to mid-on
a bit of spin there, but not a lot of bounce. Worked to cover
very flat and crunched straight to extra cover
close! He's rapped on the boot here - no he's not, he's rapped on the pads here but Taufel turns it down
cut down to third man
blimey, he's reverse sweeping here but it was far too quick for him
worked off his legs for a single
and he skips down the pitch again, and works it to leg
timed to long-on
drops this down in to the off side and scampers through for a single
done him in the flight there, balloons off his pad
worked to leg
defended on the front foot to end the over
well bowled Monty, on off stump and he's rapped on the pads trying to work it to cover
crunched to cover. Too wide of the off stump
defended on the front foot
oh well bowled, but also well played, angling it just past the wicketkeeper
expansively square-driven but there's a sweeper out there
on leg stump, he turns it round the corner for a single. He'll have to hurry, mind - but he does
on leg stump and it's worked to leg
too short and it's cut hard into the covers
he runs down the pitch but is beaten in the flight and is rapped on the pads. Vaughan appeals with a surprisingly high-pitched voice
swept to a short fine leg
clubbed down the ground
back on his stumps, he turns it around the corner to steal the strike
short and wide, cut with a flourish by Kevin out to deep extra
pushed to short midwicket
turned around leg to Mahmood
swept to deep backward square leg. In perfect control of that stroke
hurrah, at last - a four. And a fine shot too, calmly lofting it over the top, inside out, over cover. Well played that man
rapped on his pads but it's drifting down....no it's not, he's out! Taufel has raised his finger.
one step, blocked

lovely bowling, O'Brien deceived by a beautifully flighted delivery and left stranded, Nixon whips off the bails and Vaughan has a grin bigger than the Cheshire Cat. O'Brien played a super little knock, and a disappointing end getting out to what amounts to a part-time bowler
blocked, he learned from the previous delivery
swept, not quite to the pitch of the ball
Vaughan has the batsmen on the defensive after that wicket - he suddenly looks like England's No. 1 spinner
again tossed up, pushed back to the bowler
a big stride forward to defend
pushed through at almost 60mph, outside off and a big swish from White misses and the ball almost takes Nixon's head off
pushed into the off side
another big mow at one outside off, again he misses by a mile and more self-defence from Nixon as the ball flies at his head
paddled of the pad to short fine leg
into the off side, again fired in with pace at almost 60mph
a good 10mph slower than Panesar, pushed into the leg side
prodded into the covers
well flighted, really tossed up at 42mph, Johnston down the track and squirts it into the leg side
reverse sweep, misses the bat and loops up off the front pad, Nixon takes and unleashes an appeal, supported by nobody else
turned round to Panesar down in the deep on the leg side
Johnston leans back and puts everything into a back foot pull which clears the square-leg boundary by some way
worked behind square on the leg side, the man in the deep fields with ease
drifts to the off, Johnston launches an expansive drive to long-off
White perseveres with attempts to slog-sweep from outside off, and again he misses
dropped into the off side
placed wide of mid-on
Johnston aims a wipe that would have sent the ball way over cow corner, he misses, Nixon whips off the bails and appeals, Billy Doctrove doesn't even ask for the TV umpire
punched off the back foot through the covers, the man in the deep mops up
Anderson's compass needs recalibrating ... that was speared down the leg side from wide in the crease, so it looked even worse than it was. Nixon scurries across to field
better, on the stumps and blocked
Johsnton takes a step to leg and hammers the ball way over the midwicket boundary ... a dozen or so rows back, but banks of empty seats so no chance of spectator heroics
it's all going Percy Sonn ... flung down the leg side, Johnston shimmies out of the way and Nixon again has to dirty his blues to stop the ball
Anderson recovers and finds roughly the right area
full toss on leg stump, clipped to the deep square boundary where Panesar fields
White steps to leg and aims to thump the ball back past the bowler, he gets it off the toe of the bat and Anderson tumbles more than dives to his right to lie on the ball
he opens with a bouncer that flies about three feet over Johnston's head
wide, the drive evades cover's dive but third man round to mop up. 84mph ...
slower ball No. 1 - 64mph - well spotted and dug out
No. 2 - Johnston sees it, waits, and steers the ball down to third man
short and wide, White slashes, finds the edge, and the ball races down to the rope over what would have been second slip
yorker-length, on leg stump, clipped down to long leg
short and wide again, Johnston winds up and slashes that over backward point and all the way
Anderson again bowls too wide, and White slams that through the covers
full, turned into space on the on side
slower ball - 69mph - or perhaps he's just tired ... anyway, Johnston swings and misses
full toss on leg stump, thwacked into the deep
slower ball, pushed to cover, Pietersen picks up and throws, shatters the stumps at the non-striker's end ... the batsman was in, but the ball scoots away and they run an overthrow
fullish once more, and tickled into a gap on the leg
slow, Johsnton waits and smacks that over the covers, Panesar chases and taps the ball back on the rope
super shot, White stands tall and cracks that through the covers, timed and Panesar chases but he has no chance
Collingwood concentrates on line and length, good response
swung to leg, an edge loops high fine, safe as the man is up
wide, White reaches and cuts to backward point. That was a four ball ...
another slower ball, slogged to deep midwicket
full, well driven past extra cover, quick running and they scamper back for two
good yorker, but well played and backward point misses the ball which squirms past him as he is wrong footed, and third man has to mop up
White steps to the off, clips a ball up in the blockhole into a gap on the leg side
full toss on off stump, slammed through the covers to the man on the rope
full, Johnston aims a wild swing over midwicket, misses, and the ball clatters his leg stump
McCallan reaches for that outside off and works the ball through point
leg stumpish, swung high over square leg.  Collingwood was fooled by White's first movement, which was to leg, and he then shuffled to the off
far too wide, White swishes and a thick edge scurries along the ground for four, too fine for the man at wide third man
Collingwood goers wide again, White misses but that should be a wide if there is consistency
slower ball, White leans back and hammers that into the leg side, long-on has to run 30 yards to his right to field five yards in from the rope

White tries to paddle the ball round to leg, Collingwood bowls wide outside off stump and there is no way the batsman can scoop it round from there, it lobs  off the face of the bat high into the air and Nixon runs ten yards back to take the simplest of catches
tipped into the off side, he pinches the strike

super yorker-length delivery, the bat comes down just in time and the ball squirts away fine on the off side ... Flintoff and Nixon appeal and the umpire gives it out. I would like to see that again ... well, the replay looks for all the world that the ball came off the outside edge, but perhaps there was boot first ... all a bit incolnclusive
full, jammed into the off side for a quick single
again full - Flintoff has a rhythm now - and a single to the off
outside off stump, a bit of a push, Nixon and Flintoff both go up for the catch but Billy Doctrove remains unphased
beats him outside off, but this time not near the edge
full toss, a thick edge flies to the left of Nixon and he is down and across quickly to gather one handed. A good stop made to look easy
a step to leg and pushed to the man in the deep in the covers
onto the front foot and played to cover
steered to point for a quick single, and had the throw at the bowler's end hit, then the batsman, who was ambling, would have gone
outside off, misses with an attempted prod
Rankin moves towards leg stump and misses outside off
steered to point where Vaughan misfields
into the off side for a strolled single
another well-directed yorker, through a indecisive swish, and the leg stump is sent spinning
